transcripts.text: Welcome to the third installment of the 538 2020 Democratic primary draft.  It's been a while since we last did one of these, not since January.  We also recently had a debate on Tuesday, so it's time to take stock of where things are in the primary race.  But before we do, let's mention who we all picked.  the last time we did this.  It was January, remember?  I don't remember.  Elizabeth Warren, solid pick, I know.  Nate, you picked Kamala Harris.  Claire, you picked Beto O'Rourke.  And Micah, you picked Amy Klobuchar.  So that was all of our first picks.  I feel pretty confident that I won that draft.
We were trying to be contrarian, weren't we?
No, we were trying to pick who we thought were actually going to win.

No, that's wrong.  We were trying to be contrarian.  I remember being very annoyed by the fact that Biden and Bernie, who seemed like the obvious candidates, I don't think you were trying to be contrarian with Kamala Harris.

Anyway, let's do this again.  And so we're going to figure out the order with our trusty Treefort Music Festival hat, back from when we were all in Idaho, if you remember.  In which city?  In Boise.  Here we go.  And I'm going to be boring but consistent, and I'm going to pick Elizabeth Warren.  In Tuesday night's debate, we got to see what it looked like when the rest of the field considered Elizabeth Warren as a frontrunner and spent the majority of their energy basically attacking her policies in particular.  Mean Pete.  This was back when, this picture was taken when it was Nice Pete.  But we got the opportunity to see how she would respond and how she would withstand those kinds of attacks.  I don't think that we're going to see significant movement in the polls away from her after the Tuesday night debate, which means that she will still be polling in the mid 20s to almost 30% nationally, still doing well in Iowa, still doing well in New Hampshire.  That puts her in a good position to win the Democratic nomination.

In point of fact, our post-debate poll with Ipsos showed Warren got the highest rating on average for her debate performance.  and the share of voters considering voting for her didn't increase by a ton, but it increased a bit, which is meaningful because she was already one of the top two.  But electability is maybe, is that a problem for her?
Should the woman address this?
Please.

Actually, I don't think that one.  Yeah, I mean, you've kind of seen this consistently since probably January polling, where her poll numbers have gone up, but her unfavorables have sort of remained the same, even as she's risen.  So yeah, I think to use a more precise description, rather than electable or not electable, people are worried about her performance in the upper Midwest, basically.  Is she too far away for states where the Democrats do actually probably need to win back some people who voted for Trump?

I think it is worth saying, too, though, the last time we did this in January, Elizabeth Warren was not polling at the top of the pack.  And all the people polling at the top of the pack were men.  And we kept asking on the podcast, in chats, are Democrats unwilling to kind of vote for a woman in this primary?  I think they've made it clear at this point that they are willing to and that, you know, arguably right now in the Democratic primary race, a woman is the frontrunner.
So somebody might have something to say about that.

Or co-frontrunner, but at least either frontrunner or co-frontrunner.  And also under some of the hardest circumstances for her in a debate, she, as you mentioned, improved her standing with voters.  So I think that says a lot for her chances.  Claire, you are up next.  Who's your pick?

I'm going to go with Joe Biden, former senator from Delaware.  Biden is the co-frontrunner.  Where's Warren?  Biden and Warren are, we're calling them now, co-frontrunners.  Although Biden, I think, is still in the national average of polls.  Kind of leading.  A pre-debate average.
You never know.  Pre-debate average.
Thank you very much.  I just love that we now have video of Claire.

Joe.  Biden is an interesting co-frontrunner, in part because I think a lot of people in the media and probably on the very vocal political parts of Twitter, which I think 538 readers probably read a lot of, he's not well liked.  But I think he is, for a lot of people, a sort of steady at the till choice.  He's, you know, there are a couple of moderate candidates, Buttigieg and Klobuchar, obviously in that more or trying to be in that moderate lane.  But Biden is kind of the leader in that space.  And as I wrote in a piece a couple of weeks back, which you should totally check out, called The Front Runner?  Biden has a real base of support with black voters, which I don't think we should.  We can't sort of take that for granted for all these candidates.  You know, where I think his frontrunnership is a little bit wobbly is he's not doing that well in Iowa.  Pete's coming for him in Iowa.  His campaign has kind of said, oh, he doesn't need to win Iowa.  Warren is leading in New Hampshire.  And so that kind of leaves Biden with, I've got to win South Carolina.  I've got to do well on Super Tuesday.  But who knows where that momentum could leave him.  So Joe is my pick.
I think to back that up, right, since all of this Ukraine scandal talk came out, we saw that Joe Biden hasn't lost anything in the polls, really.
Yeah, he's basically steady, maybe even gained like half a point or something.
All right, Nate, your pick next.  Who are you going with?
I feel like very often in these things I wind up being the one.
Don't be contrarian.

Despite my reputation that drafts Bernie Sanders, and this is going to be one of those times where I would say Bernie Sanders is the third most likely nominee.  I think there's a debate between one of the candidates.  I don't want to spoil that in case that candidate becomes underrated later on.  But let's not overthink it.  Bernie is currently third in the polls.  I thought he had a strong debate.  Actually, in our poll, the news was a bit more mixed for him.  But, you know, I thought he was one of his more effective versions of himself.  He just announced that at least two of the four members of the so-called squad have endorsed him, including AOC.  I don't want to overthink it.
He has a lot of money.
Loyal group of supporters.  You could argue for... Maybe one or two other candidates being in third place instead.  I do think there is a big drop-off between one, two, and then three here.
In the polling, there is a big drop-off, right?  I mean, there's like 10 points between Bernie Sanders and the next person in the polls.

So to me, the kind of best theory that fits the evidence right now is Bernie Sanders, though he's had a huge influence on the party, is a factional candidate.  So even though he's up in the polls on some other people, I don't think he's more likely to win the nomination.
Let's not overplay the narrative of the race.  Fundamentally, he's in third place in the polls.  He's in first place, or second place in fundraising, right?
His cash on hand is wild.  He has 30-some million, which is well above any other candidate.  Cash on hand is very good.
You know, I mean, the age thing.  I mean, there are a lot of liabilities, right?  I'm just saying, like...
Everyone else has liabilities, too.
And he is clear positive.
All right, Micah, you get two picks.  Double pick.  As we're doing a snake draft.

Okay, I want to pick Pete Buttigieg.  I think Buttigieg is fairly self-explanatory.  He's not doing great in national polls, but if you look at polls of Iowa, of New Hampshire, he's in double digits.  I thought he raised a ton in the third quarter.  I thought he had a good debate on Tuesday night.  Our poll with Ipsos bared that out.  He got good ratings.  I think it's pretty straightforward how you can imagine a world in which Buttigieg wins Iowa, gets a ton of money, gets a ton of momentum, goes on to bigger and better things.  Where things get interesting, though, is in who you pick next.  The reason I went with Kamala Harris instead of Amy Klobuchar is because Harris has had a higher ceiling so far in the debate, and I guess I'm trying to overcome a little bit of a recency bias.  Klobuchar had a really good night on Tuesday night.  Her electability scores in our Ipsos poll went up.  The share of voters considering her went up.  It was probably her best debate.  Not even probably, it was her best debate.
Well, yeah, it's kind of a little bar to clear.  Yeah.  But she has gotten better, I think, in each subsequent debate.

She was a much more... It was kind of like Revenge of the Moderates, where she was one of two people, but it was Buttigieg and Klobuchar who were really going after Warren, kind of... full stop, and Klobuchar, you know, said some interesting things along the lines of, like, listen, Elizabeth, you're not the only one with plans.  Like, just because my plan doesn't seek to upend the entire system doesn't mean it isn't thoughtful and good.  She's trying to basically appeal at this point to people in Iowa.  That's where she has an in.  So... If that's her work, she kind of did that last night.

I have a question for you, though, Micah.  Because it seems to me like voters have had plenty of opportunities to make their assessment of Kamala Harris.  She's gotten a lot of media.  She was up in the polls.  At the start of the race, she got a lot of attention.  After the first debate, she got a lot of attention.  And it seems like voters have decided that they're not really into her.  Whereas someone like Amy Klobuchar has not really been assessed by voters nationally.  So it would seem like... We already know how voters feel about Kamala Harris, whereas Amy Klobuchar is potentially more of a wild card.

I don't know.  Maybe we should wait and see, like, okay, she already has a bigger media platform than Klobuchar.  She has more money.  She's decided she's focusing on Iowa as a way to, like, prove her electability elsewhere.
It's sort of a similar case.  to think back to where Warren was in January when she was languishing in the polls, and it sort of felt, we kept asking, why isn't Warren doing better?
Why is she so anemic in the polls?
Even then she was like at eight and not like four.

Well, here's the thing, though.  Even then her name recognition was pretty high.  So I think there is validity to the idea of like.  voters have had their look at Harris.  But to Claire's point, as we get closer to Iowa, more and more voters will be in the room looking, right?  The kind of audience increases.  And also to Nate's point, if you want to explain Harris's decline, in terms of campaign mistakes, well, that's all the more reason that she could turn it around, right?  Because you can shake up your campaign, right?  At one point, she was at like 20% in the polls.  Klobuchar's never been there.
Was she really?
She got 20%.  One or two pulls.  I think her max out average was 15.  But yeah, we'll give it to you.  We'll give it to you.  Rounding up.
I'm not going to cherry pick for you.
That's not, okay.
Cherry picking the pulls, Micah.  All right, next we got Nate.  Back to you, because we're doing a snake draft.
I will pick Amy Klobuchar.
Char!
Look.  There is an exponential decline as you get from like one and two down to, when are we at?  Six.  And there's one big barrier for Amy Kay, which is that...
What is happening?
Trying not to say her last name so I don't get yelled at.  For Amy Kay, which is that she has not yet qualified for the next debate in November.
Oh, that's another reason to pick Harris.

Again, in theory, not qualifying for the debate is not necessarily a... death sentence.  but practically we've seen that if you don't get in a debate and the media ignores you even more um.  but at this point if we're banking on long shots occurring there is upside to klobuchar in a couple of ways.  where number one she would figure to be a strong candidate in iowa.  she is the only candidate um from a state that borders iowa i believe or at least the only major candidate.
I think that's right.  Indiana does not border Iowa.  Right.

She is marginally more lively in Iowa polls than she is nationally, you know, sometimes getting in the mid single digits instead of the very low single digits.  She did, along with Mayor Pete and Warren, do well across a variety of metrics in our poll with Ipsos of the debate.  And if you have Biden collapse, she's probably the most explicitly moderate candidate in the race and someone who can make some good arguments about electability.  So it's an interesting portfolio.  of, like, long-shot chances with some really obvious problems, too.
No, and the biggest problem is what you just got at, which is it's hard to imagine Klobuchar doing well unless Biden collapses.
How does she get over Buttigieg, though?  Because isn't there some argument that if Biden collapses, Buttigieg picks up some of that support?
She gets people who say they want a woman.
All right, Claire, you are up next with seventh.  Doing it for the internet.
That's right, that's right.  No, okay.
Pandering, pandering to the internet, Claire.

No, I'm actually, okay, I think that Andrew Yang First of all, in Tuesday's debate, actually did very well.  Andrew Yang learned how to debate.  And honestly, if you think of all the candidates and where they started from, this guy has made the biggest improvement and probably made the most of his platform and everything.  He's also polling, I believe, correct me if I'm wrong, higher than Cory Booker, higher than Beto O'Rourke.  He has... fundraising numbers, he got... He has...
He has fundraising numbers.
There are numbers?  Math?  No, in terms of cash on hand.

Yeah, tons of cash on hand.  But I think, you know, more than that, he's also like... someone who's actually been able to influence some of the conversation.  I mean, you saw Castro on stage last night say, I would consider piloting UBI, Universal Basic Income, which is what the regular name for Andrew Yang's freedom dividend is.  I think he's been able to expand his message.  I think he's kind of going for the outsidery appeal, which maybe is going to siphon off some younger Bernie Sanders voters.  But also, maybe the people who like Warren and kind of like that policy-focused thing are kind of going to say, all right, like Andrew Yang, I'll give you a try.  I don't think he's, I'm like.  actually, in the past couple of weeks, I've come around to, he's actually like a pretty decent candidate.

I mean, it's easy for me, if we're looking back at the Wikipedia page of the 2020 Democratic primary a year from now, if Andrew Yang got like the third most votes That wouldn't surprise me, because he has no real incentive to drop out, right?
Oh, because he's got a small, loyal base, right?
He's the Kasich?
Not the end anymore, but yeah.
Well, he's like one of the Pauls.  I'm not sure he's ever gonna become like a universal basic candidate.  That's some terrible pun.
Ha ha ha ha!  Okay.  He also went toe-to-toe with Warren on actual policy details on automation and trade and things like that, where the other candidates seem to fall somewhat flat.
Wonderful.  That's all wonderful.  Is he more likely to win the Democratic nomination than Cory Booker, Julian Castro?
Yeah, that's the argument she's making.
I don't think so.  I think that is bonkers.
No, it's not.
The Gettys don't like Castro.
To win the Democratic nomination, to do well.  I think if we got into that world, I think you would see a wholesale movement on the part of Democratic elites to get someone else.
That's what happened in 2016 with the Republicans and Donald Trump.
No, it's not what happened.
Hey, Micah, Trump.
Republican elites never made a move.
Your argument is that Democratic elites are fundamentally different than Republicans when it comes to the party decides?
My hunch would be that Democratic elites learned lessons from what Republicans did wrong in 2016 and would act accordingly.

All right, final pick, I'm going to go with Cory Booker.  I think for the same reason I argued that Amy Klobuchar maybe should be considered ahead of Kamala Harris, and that's because he hasn't had his opportunity to be considered by the broader public yet.  and the people who know him like him, he has a positive message.  I think in a campaign where people are going to try to draw contrasts with the president, that positive message, we all need to have common values or common goals, et cetera, could resonate.  We're eight picks in now, so I'm not saying his chances are likely, but if something crazy happens, And we are down to, you know, the third tier.  It's not Michael Avenatti.  I do think it would, in fact, be Cory Booker.
I mean,
I think that's I mean,
it's all
peace and love.
Yeah, but he's a very good speaker on the stump.
He's very good.

He has a potential way in with Iowa, right?  He could play happy warrior, friendly guy.  He also has a potential in South Carolina.  He's a black candidate.  That's a state where the electorate is two-thirds black.  There's a lot of ways I think Cory Booker, to me, he has been consistently, even though I picked Andrew Yang, the person who has the most potential to pop.
You know what it felt like Cory Booker's head was at in the debate though?  I think Cory Booker was thinking about What a nice ticket.
Ooh, hot take.  That would make my picks pretty good because I picked Elizabeth Warren and Cory Booker.  Or this.
That could be an interesting ticket.
You mean this though, right?
Someone said to me after Tuesday night's debate that they thought that Cory Booker seemed like he was running for VP.
He'd be a good VP.
And he'd be a possible VP for the two, according to us, leading candidates.
For sure.  He'd be a good VP nominee.  Can we say a couple interesting things about people who weren't picked?
Say a couple interesting things.  Really quick?  What do you got to say about Tulsi?
